string-array.name: introduction_cont
string-array.item: SnoreDebby is an app that records, measures and tracks your snoring. It helps thousands of people just like you to gain insights into their snoring. \n\nYou can share SnoreDebby’s reports with your doctor or dentist, or experiment with snoring remedies and lifestyle changes and track their impact over time.

string-array.name: placement_cont
string-array.item:
It is recommended placing the device next to your bed with the microphone facing towards you. Keep the charger connected if possible to ensure full night monitoring and fully charged device the next day.

Placing the device face down will dim the screen and reduce battery usage. 

Note: SnoreDebby is sensitive to ambient noise and works best in quiet environment.

string-array.name: results_cont
string-array.item:
After each night you’ll receive a report showing you when and how loudly you snored with a selection of audio samples.

You’ll also get a Snore Score for the night, which is a measure of snoring intensity. If you experiment with snoring remedies or track factors you can see how they impact your snoring by the change in your Snore Score.

Don’t worry too much about disk usage, one night of samples only contents 2-4 MB at the default setting. You can also delete unwanted sound files and optionally activate full-night recording if you want to hear everything.

string-array.name: important_disclaimer_cont
string-array.item: SnoreDebby is not a replacement for a professional sleep study and diagnosis. Snoring can be symptomatic of serious sleep disorders (see the section on obstructive sleep apnea below) and you should seek immediate medical attention if you are concerned by your symptoms.

string-array.name: what_cont
string-array.item:
Snoring is noisy breathing whilst you sleep caused by the vibration of soft tissue in your head and neck. 

The exact sound you make will depend on the types of soft tissue that is vibrating. For example, if the soft tissue at the back of your nose vibrates it is likely you will produce a pinched nasal sound. If the tissues at the top of your mouth and the back of your throat vibrate, you will produce a louder, more guttural, throaty sound. In most cases, snoring is caused by a combination of areas that are vibrating or blocked. 

While you sleep your airways relax and narrows. This affects air pressure within your airways, which causes the tissue to vibrate. This can also happen if your airways are partially blocked, for example if you have a cold.
